Guided Walkthrough

Beginner 20 min Section 3 of 7

üéØ Overview üìö Concepts üö∂ Walkthrough üíª Labs ‚úÖ Quiz üìñ Resources üíº Scenarios

Your First Git Repository

Let‚Äôs walk through creating and using a Git repository step by step.

üìã Prerequisites
- Git installed on your computer ([Download Git](https://git-scm.com/downloads)) - A text editor (VS Code recommended) - Terminal/Command Prompt access **Check if Git is installed:** ```bash git --version # Should output something like: git version 2.39.0 ```

Step 1: Configure Git (One-Time Setup)

Tell Git who you are:

git config --global user.name "Your Name"
git config --global user.email "your.email@example.com"

Verify your configuration:

git config --list
üí° Why This Matters
Every commit records who made it. This configuration appears in your commit history and GitHub contribution graphs.

Step 2: Create a Project Folder

mkdir my-first-repo
cd my-first-repo

Step 3: Initialize Git

Turn this folder into a Git repository:

git init

What you‚Äôll see:

Initialized empty Git repository in /path/to/my-first-repo/.git/

What just happened: Git created a hidden .git folder to store all history.

Step 4: Create a File

echo "# My First Repository" > README.md

Check the status:

git status

What you‚Äôll see:

On branch main

No commits yet

Untracked files:
  (use "git add <file>..." to include in what will be committed)
        README.md

nothing added to commit but untracked files present

Translation: Git sees README.md but isn‚Äôt tracking it yet (it‚Äôs untracked).

Step 5: Stage the File

Add the file to the staging area:

git add README.md

Check status again:

git status

What you‚Äôll see:

On branch main

No commits yet

Changes to be committed:
  (use "git rm --cached <file>..." to unstage)
        new file:   README.md

Translation: README.md is now staged and ready to commit.

Step 6: Make Your First Commit

git commit -m "Initial commit: Add README"

What you‚Äôll see:

[main (root-commit) a3f2b91] Initial commit: Add README
 1 file changed, 1 insertion(+)
 create mode 100644 README.md

Translation: You created commit a3f2b91 with 1 file and 1 line added.

Step 7: View Your History

git log

What you‚Äôll see:

commit a3f2b918c7f6e5d4b3a2c1e9d8f7a6b5c4d3e2f1
Author: Your Name <your.email@example.com>
Date:   Mon Dec 9 10:30:00 2025 -0500

    Initial commit: Add README

üéâ Congratulations! You‚Äôve created your first Git repository and commit!

Making More Changes

Edit the File

Add more content:

echo "This is my first Git project!" >> README.md

Check What Changed

git diff

What you‚Äôll see:

diff --git a/README.md b/README.md
index 4d1ae35..8ab12cd 100644
--- a/README.md
+++ b/README.md
@@ -1 +1,2 @@
 # My First Repository
+This is my first Git project!

Translation: Shows added lines (green +) and removed lines (red -).

Stage and Commit

git add README.md
git commit -m "Add project description to README"

Working with Branches

Create a Feature Branch

git checkout -b feature/add-about

What you‚Äôll see:

Switched to a new branch 'feature/add-about'

Make Changes on the Branch

Create a new file:

echo "# About\n\nThis project teaches Git basics." > ABOUT.md
git add ABOUT.md
git commit -m "Add ABOUT page"

View All Branches

git branch

What you‚Äôll see:

* feature/add-about
  main

The * shows your current branch.

Merging Branches

Switch Back to Main

git checkout main

Merge Your Feature

git merge feature/add-about

What you‚Äôll see:

Updating a3f2b91..d4e5f67
Fast-forward
 ABOUT.md | 3 +++
 1 file changed, 3 insertions(+)
 create mode 100644 ABOUT.md

Delete the Feature Branch

git branch -d feature/add-about

Pushing to GitHub

Now let‚Äôs connect your local repo to GitHub.

Create a Repository on GitHub

  1. Go to github.com/new
  2. Name it my-first-repo
  3. Do NOT initialize with README (we already have one)
  4. Click Create repository

Connect Local to Remote

GitHub shows you commands ‚Äî use the ‚Äúexisting repository‚Äù option:

git remote add origin https://github.com/YOUR-USERNAME/my-first-repo.git
git branch -M main
git push -u origin main

What you‚Äôll see:

Enumerating objects: 6, done.
Counting objects: 100% (6/6), done.
Compressing objects: 100% (3/3), done.
Writing objects: 100% (6/6), 548 bytes | 548.00 KiB/s, done.
Total 6 (delta 0), reused 0 (delta 0)
To https://github.com/YOUR-USERNAME/my-first-repo.git
 * [new branch]      main -> main
Branch 'main' set up to track remote branch 'main' from 'origin'.

Verify on GitHub

Refresh your GitHub repository page ‚Äî your code is now there!

Common Commands Reference

Command What It Does
git init Initialize a new repository
git status Show current state
git add <file> Stage a file
git add . Stage all changes
git commit -m "msg" Create a commit
git log View commit history
git diff Show unstaged changes
git branch List branches
git checkout -b name Create and switch to branch
git merge branch Merge branch into current
git push Upload to remote
git pull Download from remote

Coming Up Next

Now that you‚Äôve walked through the basics, let‚Äôs practice with hands-on labs where you‚Äôll work through common Git scenarios.
